tutorials.title: TURNS AND ROUNDS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Chronicles of Drunagor is played over a series of turns and rounds. A turn is the moment when a Character takes Actions. The round is completed when the last Character on the board finishes their Actions. The Initiative Track organizes this process.

This is the Initiative Track and Marker.

  • When the Initiative Marker reaches a Character’s card, it is their turn. When they finish their turn, move the marker to the next card.
  • After the last card on the track has been activated, the marker returns to the first card, starting the next round.
  • The turn order runs from left to right and from the top to the bottom of the track, as if it were a long straight line.

Place the End of the Round Game State Check-Up card at the bottom end of the Initiative Track. It serves as a reminder of some processes that take place at the end of each round.

This is where the End of the Round card goes on the Initiative Track.

tutorials.title: HERO TURN
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Heroes can take the following Actions during their turn, alternating between them as they choose:

  • Take up to one Move Action
  • Take up to two Cube Actions

Heroes are not required to take all the Actions they are entitled to.

We will begin by learning just these two types of Actions. Whenever a new type of Action becomes available to the Heroes, it will come with a complementary set of instructions much like the following.

tutorials.title: MOVE ACTION
tutorials.bodyHTML:
The Move Action is the basic way Heroes move in CoD. It grants 3 movement points that can be used to move around the board.

  • Each square moved into costs 1 movement point.
  • Diagonal movement is allowed and does not cost additional points.
  • Movement up or down board levels does not cost additional points, as long as the change is only one level for each square moved.
  • Heroes can travel through (but not stop in) squares occupied by their allies. They cannot travel through those occupied by enemies, though.
  • Heroes do not need to use all their movement points.
  • If a Hero is moving and decides to take a Cube Action while they still have movement points to spend, those points are lost.

If a Hero wants to take another Move Action in the same turn, they may use a Cube Action to do so: They discard 1 Action Cube from their Pool to take an additional Move Action with 3 movement points, placing the discarded Cube in their “Expended Cubes Box” on their Hero board.

tutorials.title: CUBE ACTION
tutorials.bodyHTML:
“Cube Action” is the name given to any Action where a Hero uses an Action Cube during their turn. Usually, this is to perform one of their Skills. To take a Cube Action, the Hero must spend a Cube of the appropriate color, placing it in the slot corresponding to the Skill they are using. Here are some details about these actions:

  • A Hero can only take Cube Actions during their own turn.
  • The type (color) of the Cube determines the Range for all effects of that Skill:
    • Melee (yellow): Targets Characters adjacent to the Hero.
    • Ranged (red): Targets Characters within Range 1, that is, in any square in the same area (blue square) or in an area adjacent to the one the Hero is in.
    • Agility (green) or Wisdom (blue): Targets Characters anywhere on the board.
    • A Hero is always within Range of any effects they cast themselves.
  • Once an Action Cube is used, it remains slotted into the socket of the Skill it was used to trigger until it is Recalled through a process we’ll cover later, the Recall Action.
  • A Skill is read from left to right, paying attention to the punctuation marks:
    • The first term, followed by a colon (:), indicates the type of Targets that Skill can be used on. “SELF: SHIELD 2” – The allowed target for this effect is SELF, the Hero using this Skill.
    • Comma (,) and AND: These are used as in grammar, uniting the Keywords of a single effect. “SELF: MAKE A OF +3 TO HIT, KEEN, AND +2 DMG” – This Attack has 3 Keywords: +3 TO HIT, KEEN, and +2 DMG.
    • Semicolon (;): Separates two different effects of the same Skill. “SELF: SHIELD 2; ANY TARGET: 2 DMG” – This Skill has two effects. The first of these grants SHIELD 2 to the Hero using it. The second, in turn, deals 2 DMG to any Target within Range.

Cube Actions are the main abilities that Heroes use, and the effects of each Keyword can be found in the Summary. For this Tutorial, each Hero has the ones they use most explained on their Hero Boards.

tutorials.title: MAKING WEAPON ATTACKS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
There is no basic action to Attack in CoD. Attacks are effects provided by Skills and Abilities that the Hero casts, just like any other effect.

Weapon Attack instructions follow the pattern “MAKE A OF +X TO HIT”, followed by any other Keywords that apply to that Attack.

  • The type (color) of the Cube used to trigger the Skill that includes the Attack determines its Range:
    • Melee (yellow): The Attack can hit enemies adjacent to the Hero.
    • Ranged (red): The Attack can hit enemies that are in the same area (blue square) the Hero is in or the area adjacent to it. Heroes who are adjacent to enemies, however, cannot make Ranged (red) . This is called “Combat Engagement”.
  • The player rolls the D20 and adds any TO HIT bonuses (+X TO HIT). If the Roll equals or exceeds their Weapon’s Accuracy value (in the blue diamond), the Attack hits and causes the damage indicated on that Weapon card, plus any damage bonuses the Attack has.
    • If the Roll is a “natural” 20 (value rolled before any modifiers), the Attack is a Critical Hit—It deals double damage.
    • If the Roll is a “natural” 1, the Attack is a Critical Failure—They miss even if the To Hit bonus would be enough to hit.
  • Attacks made by a Hero who is on a board level above their Target gain a +2 TO HIT bonus, while those made from below the Target receive a -2 TO HIT penalty.

Once these steps are completed, the Attack is complete.

Vorn is Attacking through his Arcing Strike Skill. Since Vorn’s Dwarven Warhammer has Accuracy 7 and his Skill provides a +3 TO HIT bonus, he must score at least a 4 on the D20 for the Attack to hit and deal damage.

tutorials.title: STARTGAME TRIGGER
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Now that you’ve completed the first Tutorial readings, place the Initiative Marker on Vorn’s (or the Hero who is playing the Defender role if it is not Vorn) Initiative card. That Hero can move to reach a Monster and make Attacks (²) against it. For purposes of this Tutorial, if the Vampire is killed, keep it on the board with 1 Health so as not to interfere with the following Tutorials. 
You may begin to play the Adventure. Once the Defender’s turn ends (after taking their Move Action and Two Cube Actions), move the Initiative marker to the next card, the Vampire Monster, and read “The Monsters’ Turn” and “Reactions” in the Tutorial tab of your app.

tutorials.title: THE MONSTERS’ TURN
tutorials.bodyHTML:
When the Initiative Marker reaches a Monster card, every Monster of that type takes its turn. ACTIVATING a Monster is done by following the four steps below. All the information you need for the behavior and abilities of that type of Monster is described on its card.

  • First, any Conditions that are affecting the Monster are triggered. This can lead to the death of that Monster if Persistent Damage (BLEED, BURN, or POISON) is among these Conditions.
  • Secondly, they “aim” at their Target for this ACTIVATION.
    • Monsters can target different types of Heroes. In this tutorial, all Monsters have the “Strongest Hero” as their primary Target.
    • Monsters prefer to target Heroes they can reach, given their movement ability. Therefore, they always target the “Strongest Hero they can reach.”
    • The Strongest Hero is the one who currently has the most Health Points. In case of a tie, the Monster chooses the one who acts first on the Initiative Track among those tied for the most Health Points.
    • If they cannot reach any Heroes, Monsters will use their movement to get as close to one as possible.
  • Third, they move towards their Target, if necessary.

Monsters always follow the shortest path possible.

  • Finally, they attack, causing the damage indicated on their card. Monsters do not roll the D20; They always hit.

Heroes may use Reactions () to protect themselves. Any damage dealt that is not mitigated by PREVENT effects or SHIELD tokens reduces their Health Points.

If there are two or more Monsters of the same type on the board, ACTIVATE the “fastest” one among them first, following the order on the Monster Status board: Monsters with a yellow base are the “fastest” while those with a brown base are the “slowest”.

At this point in the tutorial, the first Monster to act may need to move to reach the Strongest Hero.

tutorials.title: REACTIONS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Reactions () can be used whenever any Hero is Threatened—that is, when PREVENTABLE DAMAGE is about to be dealt to their Health Points.

  • Reactions can be used on both the Heroes’ and Monsters’ turns.
  • To perform a Reaction, the Hero spends an Action Cube of the appropriate color, as they would when using a Skill as a Cube Action.
  • Reactions, however, are not Cube Actions. Therefore, even if a Hero has not taken their turn yet or they have already taken both of their Cube Actions for this round, they can still use as many Reactions as they want.
  • Each Hero can only use 1 Reaction per Threat.
  • If any damage is dealt to Heroes who have SHIELD tokens, these tokens are discarded first. If they are enough to reduce the damage to 0, no Threat is generated.
  • Heroes can React to Threats to other Heroes, but only if their Reaction can choose “ANY TARGET” as its Target. Reactions with “SELF” can only be used by Heroes to protect themselves.

Once you have finished reading this topic, place the Recall Action Tutorial Trigger card at the bottom end of the Initiative Track, just above the End of the Round Game State Check-Up card.

This is where the Recall Action Tutorial Trigger card goes on the Initiative Track.

You may proceed with the Adventure. The Vampires will now ACTIVATE, and at least one of them (if not more) will Attack a Hero with enough strength to cause a Threat.

tutorials.title: RECALL ACTION
tutorials.bodyHTML:
By exchanging blows with Monsters, the Heroes’ Action Cube Pools will eventually run out. Whenever this is the case, the Heroes can take Recall Actions to replenish them.

Recall Actions can be Willing or Unwilling.

Willing Recall Actions can be taken by the Hero during their turn if they only have Action Cubes of two or fewer colors in their Pool. However, if a Hero chooses to take a Recall Action this way, their turn ends immediately.

Unwilling Recall Actions, on the other hand, are taken immediately whenever a Hero spends their last Action Cube and their Pool is empty. This, however, does not end their turn.

When taking a Recall Action, the Hero returns all their Action Cubes allocated to Skills or their Expended Action Cube box back to their Pool.

Recall actions are not free: Heroes receive a penalty whenever they take one, after collecting their Cubes. At the beginning of this Adventure, this penalty is 1 Curse Cube.

This is an example of a Recall Action, no matter what type.

tutorials.title: CURSE CUBES
tutorials.bodyHTML:
• Curse Cubes represent the physical, spiritual, and mental exhaustion that Heroes experience. They are usually acquired as a penalty for Recall Actions.
  • Curse Cubes are the black cubes. The Hero must allocate them to their available Skills when they are received, blocking them from using those Skills.

Curse Cubes remain on the Hero’s board until removed by CLEANSE effects.

Vorn has chosen to block Dwarven Breath with a Curse Cube he received after taking a Recall Action (this might not have happened yet within your tutorial).

  • If any Hero accumulates 6 Curse Cubes at the same time, they are corrupted and the Adventure ends immediately! This is another way for the Party to be defeated.

Once you have finished reading these topics, place the Folding Doors Tutorial Trigger card at the end of the Initiative Track, just above the End of Round card. Proceed with the Adventure. The next turn on the Initiative Track is the End of the Round Game State Check-Up card. No Hero will be able to open a Door, so the Initiative marker just returns to the Defender’s card, starting a new round. This round will follow the same dynamic as the previous one, with the exception that, at the end of it, the Folding Doors Tutorial card will be read before the next round begins.

tutorials.title: FOLDING DOORS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Dungeon crawling in CoD involves opening Doors to reveal new places and challenges.

  • In Drunagor Nights, Doors can only be opened at the end of the round.
  • To open a Door, a Hero must be adjacent to it and choose to do so after the Rune card (the last card on the track) is triggered.
  • Doors cannot be opened as long as there is a Monster on the board.

Once you have finished reading this topic, each Hero repositions their model in one of the squares on Map DNE2-F. At least one Hero must place their model in a square adjacent to the Door. Proceed with the Adventure, taking the End of Round card turn. A Hero must then open the Door.

tutorials.title: POPULATING A ROOM
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Doors have instructions for the next Setup, indicating which Maps, Monsters, and other elements must be placed on the board. In Drunagor Nights, especially for players not yet familiar with CoD, it’s likely that the trays, Maps, and Doors will already be set up in advance. So, when opening a Door, the only task will be to populate the room.

These instructions were explained once during the First Setup, but you can review the process again here:

  • Place all the elements described in the Setup instructions until you reach the number of Heroes in the Party. If there are 3 Heroes, for example, place all elements listed for 2+ and 3+.
  • Whenever a Monster is summoned, place its card on the Initiative Track, in the position indicated by the Rune and the arrow on that card.
  • Place each Monster in the indicated positions, attaching a colored base to each. The bases match the colors on the Monster Status board. The order and colors of these bases do not matter.
  • Mark the Health Points of each Monster on the Monster Status board. Their initial (and maximum) value is indicated on their cards.

NOTE: Drunagor Nights sessions are designed for a minimum and maximum of 2 to 4 Heroes, unlike the Core Box. CoD – Age of Darkness can be played from True Solo mode up to 5 players. The instructions there are presented starting from 1+, up to 5+.

tutorials.title: RANGED MONSTERS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Some Monsters can Attack from a distance. This does not change their overall behavior, but it does introduce some new things you must consider. They are subject to the same restrictions as a Hero when making a Ranged Attack:

  • Ranged Monsters can attack enemies up to 1 area (blue square) away, but are subject to Combat Engagement.
  • A Ranged Monster will not Target a Hero if they would have to be in Combat Engagement in order to hit them. Instead, they will Target the next Hero in their order of priority.
  • Ranged Monsters that are Engaged will move away from the Heroes who are obstructing their attack whenever necessary.

Once you have finished reading these topics, place the Interaction Tutorial Trigger card at the bottom end of the Initiative Track, just above the End of Round card, then proceed with the Adventure.

The Rotten Monster introduced in this Setup has a Passive Skill: Attack Twice, meaning in short that it takes two Attack Actions when activated (but only a single Move Action).

tutorials.title: INTERACTIONS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
CoD is not only about moving and fighting. The world is also full of scenes called Interactions: dilemmas where the players must decide how to act, which can affect the story in many ways, positive or negative.

  • The Hero responsible for the Interaction must choose one of the resolutions shown.
  • Each resolution of an Interaction can only be chosen once, even if a different Hero is able to interact with it later.

Interactions can reward Heroes with Items or cause small changes to the Adventure narrative and gameplay.

tutorials.title: ITEMS I
tutorials.bodyHTML:
This Interaction may reward the Heroes with some Items. Items are represented in the game by cards, and these cards come in two types: Equipment is gear that a Hero can wield in the matching Slot on the right side of their board; Consumable Items, on the other hand, are single-use treasures stored in their Bag.

  • Check your Hero’s proficiencies—They can only wield Equipment of those types.
  • If the Item is Equipment and the Hero is proficient, they can choose to wield it. Move any cards currently occupying the appropriate Slot to their Bag.
  • If the Item is Equipment and the Hero is not proficient, move that card straight to their Bag.
  • Each Hero’s Bag can carry up to two Items at a time. If a third Item is placed in it, the player must discard one of the three cards without applying its effects (if it is a Consumable Item).
  • When a Consumable Item is used, the player discards its card.

Once you have finished reading these topics, each Hero and Pet repositions their model in a square of their choice on Map DNE4-F. At least one Hero must choose a square that is adjacent to the Door. Then, go to Interaction – “The Barricade”. A Hero who is adjacent to the Door is responsible for this Interaction: The decision is theirs, but you should discuss the options together.

tutorials.title: LEARNING NEW SKILLS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
At the end of each CoD Adventure, the players will improve their Heroes to prepare them for new challenges. The first type of these progressions is Learning New Hero Skills.

  • Heroes can only learn Hero Skills on their own cards.
  • Each Hero Skill card has two sides—The front side corresponds to Level 1 of that Skill while the back corresponds to Level 2.
  • Whenever they learn a new Skill, a Hero will be able to learn Level 1 of a new Skill Tree or upgrade a Level 1 Skill they already have to Level 2.
  • Whenever a Hero learns or upgrades a Skill, they receive 1 Action Cube of the color associated with that Skill.

At this point, each Hero gets to learn a new Level 1 Skill. Remember to collect the appropriate Action Cubes from the Reserve. Each Hero will now have a Pool of 6 Action Cubes.

tutorials.title: COMMANDERS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Some creatures develop magical mutations that make them much more dangerous. They are the Commanders of Darkness. They have special game mechanics, functioning as “Mini-Bosses” in an Adventure.

  • Commanders gain extra Actions each round. These are represented by Commander Attack cards that are ACTIVATED when the Initiative Marker reaches them. Commanders draw a number of Attack cards equal to the number of Heroes.
  • Take the deck of Commander Attack cards (golden back), shuffle it, and draw one card for each Hero in the Adventure, placing them in the appropriate slots on the Track.
  • Attack cards explain their own effects, like a Skill.
    • The “X” value corresponds to the number of Runes of that color on the Initiative Track.
    • For this tutorial, however, the Commander requires a handicap to be balanced with the Heroes. Therefore, treat any value written as “X” as “Half of X (rounded down).”
  • Commander Monster cards, in turn, work like any other Monster card: When the Initiative Marker reaches it, the Commander ACTIVATES and takes its Move and Attack Actions.
  • The Corrupted Gatekeeper will have 16, 32, 48, or 64 Health, depending on the number of Heroes. If you are interested, the equation that determines a Commander’s Health Points is described here:
    • Commander Health = CP (described by the Setup with a number added or multiplied by the number of Heroes) times by R (Health Points on the Commander card).

In addition to being a Commander, the Corrupted Gatekeeper is also a Large Monster, and its size imposes some special rules.

tutorials.title: LARGE MONSTERS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Large Monsters are imposing enemies that occupy an entire area (blue square). In CoD, however, size matters, and this feature introduces some changes to the behavior of this type of Monster:

  • Large Monsters move from area to area. So, 2 movement points means they can cross 2 areas.
  • Large Monsters may move through or stop in areas occupied by smaller Monsters and/or Chests. Whenever they end their movement in an area occupied by these objects, reposition the smaller Monsters to adjacent squares around the Large Monster and remove the Chests from the board.
  • Large Monsters, however, cannot move through or stop in areas occupied by Heroes, NPC tokens, or Pets.
  • Large Monsters attack entire areas that are adjacent to their models. They hit every enemy in that area instead of just one Target.
  • Large Monsters prioritize hitting as many Heroes as they can over hitting the Strongest Hero.
  • If they manage to reach the same number of Heroes in different combinations, they prioritize the one with the Strongest Hero among them.
  • Pets do not count towards a Large Monster’s Target priority. However, they may be attacked “by association” if they are in an area that is hit by a Large Monster.
  • Large Monsters are Immune to KNOCK DOWN, PUSH, STUN, and TELEKINESIS. These Immunities are represented by the “LARGE” icon.

Remember, the Special Rule – “Plot Armor” is still in effect. Once you have finished reading these topics, continue the Adventure on your own until you defeat the Commander and manage to open the next Door. This time, there is no Scene Trigger. The Heroes need to remember to open the Door.

tutorials.title: MINOR ACTIONS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Heroes may take a third type of Action in addition to Move Actions and Cube Actions: the Minor Action. Each Hero may take one of each of these actions during their turn to perform special tasks such as:

  • Loot a Chest.
    • When they do so, the Heroes draw the top Chest card from the deck (the one with the image of a chest over the orange banner). Chests can contain traps in CoD, but don’t worry about that in this tutorial. These Chests are safe, and the Heroes can draw the cards without fear.
  • Give 1 Item from their Bag to another Hero.
    • Bags are magical—There is no Range limit.
  • Equip, Unequip, or Exchange Equipment.
    • Heroes do not need to have free space in their Bags to Exchange Equipment.
  • Interact with an Interaction token.
  • Any other effects described as a “Minor Action”.
    • Some Dungeon Events or Class Abilities perform special effects at the cost of a Minor Action.

Later on, Heroes will learn to use what are called “Focus Abilities.” Using one of these Abilities—if it’s not marked as a Reaction ()—also counts as a Minor Action.

tutorials.title: INTERACTION TOKENS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Interactions can be represented by tokens on the board. Whenever this is the case, that scene will not automatically be presented to the Heroes as it is when the scene is triggered by opening a Door. They need to Interact with the token if they want to encounter it.

  • Heroes must be adjacent to the token to do this.
  • As stated previously, this Interaction costs a Minor Action.
  • The same rules as for the scene apply, with two exceptions:
    • The Hero who is Interacting is responsible for any decisions the scene requires.
    • When the Interaction is complete, reduce the charges of that token by 1. If that was the last charge, remove the token from the board.

Interaction tokens are Solid Objects, meaning that Characters cannot travel through a square containing one (unless they are JUMPING) or end their movement on them.

tutorials.title: DARKNESS NODES AND TIE BREAKERS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
The influence of Darkness is so strong in this hall that every now and then it condenses into nodes of pure power. These nodes can strengthen the enemy, therefore destroying them is useful for the Heroes.

  • Piles of Runes represent Darkness Nodes. They are formed by taking 1 Rune of each color from the Initiative Track.
    • Piles of Runes are Solid Objects, meaning Characters cannot travel through or stop in spaces occupied by them.
  • Heroes can take “Untie Node” actions as Cube Actions.
    • To do this, they need to be adjacent to the Pile of Runes and Expend (move it to the Expended Cube box) 1 AC of their choice.
    • When they do so, that Hero chooses a number of Runes equal to 6 minus the number of Heroes and returns them to the bag, regaining a few rounds before the Adventure ends.
    • That Hero also receives either FOCUS 1 or CLEANSE 1. If you are playing the Tutorial Adventure and Focus Abilities have not yet been introduced, Heroes may choose to receive HEAL 3 instead.

For now, Piles of Runes only slows the Adventure countdown tracker down, but there are other game mechanics that may interact with Piles of Runes in the future. So, assemble 1 Pile of Runes as shown below:

Example of assembling a Pile of Runes.

tutorials.title: PASSIVE AND TRIGGERED BONUSES
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Some Class Abilities and Skills can provide “passive” benefits. The most common types are Passive Bonuses and Triggered Effects. The terms and punctuation marks show how to manage these benefits, just like in Skills:

  • Dash (–): Separates the effect trigger from the Triggered Effect. The instruction written before the dash describes the trigger. The effect is written in the following sequence. “AT THE BEGINNING OF YOUR TURN – SELF: SHIELD 2” means that at the beginning of each of your turns, your Hero gains SHIELD 2.
    • SURGE – This term means “Whenever you get a natural 16+ on a D20 roll during a ”.
  • Passive bonuses (usually “GAIN” or “INCREASES”) define benefits that automatically improve the Hero’s actions or attributes. The effect's description states whether it applies to actions you take or effects you receive:
    • CAST – When a Hero (or their Equipment) is the source of an effect, we say that they “cast” that effect.
    • RECEIVE – When a Hero is targeted by an effect, whether they cast that effect themselves or another Hero did, we say that they “receive” that effect.
    • Consumable Item effects are also CAST and/or RECEIVED by each Hero, as appropriate.

The vast majority of Passive Skills follow this description. There are exceptions, but the text usually explains itself in these cases, as in “YOUR MAXIMUM HEALTH INCREASES BY 4”.

tutorials.title: LEARNING CLASS ABILITIES
tutorials.bodyHTML:
The second type of Progression that Heroes can receive during an Adventure is learning Class Abilities.

  • Heroes can only learn Class Abilities that belong to their Class.
  • Each Class Ability card corresponds to an ability tree. Heroes always start by learning a Level 1 Skill from a tree.
  • Whenever a Hero learns a Class Ability, mark it using 1 white cube.
  • Heroes do not need to commit to ability trees. They can start a new tree whenever they learn a new Class Ability.
  • Curse Cubes cannot be allocated to Class Abilities.

At this time, each Hero must Learn 1 Level 1 Class Ability. Do not forget to allocate a white cube to indicate the chosen Ability.

tutorials.title: MULTI-TARGET MONSTERS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
In addition to Large Monsters, some Monsters can hit more than one Hero with a single attack. This ability is indicated by the Keyword TWO TARGETS. Similar to Large Monsters, this feature introduces a small change to the Monster's behavior:

  • Multi-Target Monsters prioritize hitting as many Heroes as they can over hitting the Strongest Hero.
  • If they manage to reach the same number of Heroes in different combinations, they prioritize the one with the Strongest Hero among them.

Once you have finished reading these topics, proceed with the Adventure. The next instructions will be explained when the next Scene Trigger activates.

tutorials.title: BOSS BATTLES
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Boss battles are epic moments in CoD gameplay. In a way, the Setup and rules are the same as for Commanders, except that the Bosses are even more resistant and complex.

  • Each Boss Battle has a specific Setup (the players have already done this for the first Boss Battle).
  • Boss Attack cards determine their own effects. Just read them and apply the effects as you would with a Skill.

The “X” value corresponds to the number of Runes of that color on the Initiative Track.

  • The Boss Monster card works the same way as other Monsters: When they ACTIVATE this card, they perform their Basic Attack.
  • Conditions afflicting the Boss take effect in the turn they ACTIVATE their Monster card.

If there is any doubt when resolving an Attack card from the Undead King, refer to the clarification section for them in this tutorial.

tutorials.title: DARKNESS
tutorials.bodyHTML: Darkness is the main villain in CoD, and it is present in virtually every scenario of Age of Darkness. Two rules are associated with it: how it is placed on the board (Spawns), and the effects it applies to both Monsters and Heroes. Continue reading the Tutorial – “Spawning the Darkness.”

tutorials.title: SPAWNING THE DARKNESS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Each Adventure establishes rules for summoning the Darkness, but in AoD (Age of Darkness), they follow a pre-established pattern: In short, Darkness is summoned whenever a Rune is drawn due to the Darkness Hunting Rune card.

  • The card indicates the number of Runes that must be drawn. If 2 or more Runes are drawn for the same effect, draw 1 at a time.
  • The tile summoned onto the board is indicated by the sigil on the back of the Rune drawn. The color of the Rune doesn't matter at this point.
  • The tile must be summoned on a Darkness Spawning Point (underneath the Piles of Runes), or next to another Darkness tile that is already on the board. Darkness Maps count as Darkness tiles. At least one of the squares of the tile must be placed on the Darkness Spawning Point or touching a Darkness tile already on the board.
  • Players may position the summoned tile however they want, but it must follow the Darkness behavior: reach the Strongest Hero, or get as close to them as possible.

Players may place the tile in such a way so that only the Strongest Hero is affected by it, if they can.

  • If the summoned tile does not fit on the board, or if it does fit but the fit is not in a position that is closest to the Strongest Hero, it is split into 3 Small Darkness tiles instead.
  • If the summoned tile needs to change board levels or hang off a tray to reach the Strongest Hero, it is split into 3 Small Darkness tiles instead.
    • The 3 Small Darkness tiles are positioned in a way that reaches the Strongest Hero, if possible. If you succeed with the first or second tile placed, the remaining tiles are positioned to reach the next-Strongest Hero, and so on.
  • Darkness Tiles are not summoned if all Heroes are on Darkness tiles at the time a Rune is drawn.

Details on summoning Darkness can be found in the Rulebook. The next topic explains the effects of Darkness.

tutorials.title: DARKNESS EFFECTS
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Once on the board, Darkness becomes an obstacle for the Heroes and introduces small adaptations to the behavior of Monsters. The first effects described are for “contact”:

  • Whenever a Hero steps into a Darkness square, or ends their turn in one, they take 2 unpreventable damage.
    • This damage is only applied once per turn.
    • If a Hero steps into 2 or more squares in the same turn, they only take this damage once.
    • If a Hero steps into a square, takes damage, and then ends the same turn in that square, they do not take the damage again.
    • If a Hero steps into a square when it’s not their turn, they take the damage immediately; then, later in the round, if they end their own turn in that square, they take the damage again.
    • SHIELD tokens can protect Heroes from this damage.

The next effects are “passive”. These are bonuses and penalties that Darkness applies to Characters:

  • Heroes standing in Darkness suffer a -2 TO HIT penalty to Accuracy Tests.
  • Monsters standing in Darkness receive a +2 DMG bonus to their Basic Attack.
    • Large Monsters only need to be in 1 square of Darkness to receive this bonus.
    • This bonus only applies to Commander and Boss Monster Basic Attacks. Attack cards do not benefit from it.
  • Monsters seek the Darkness. Whenever they “aim” at a Target, if there is any Darkness square in which that Monster can end its movement without changing the Target, it will move to that square to benefit from this damage bonus.

Once you have finished reading these topics, proceed with the Adventure. This is the final fight for this Tutorial.

tutorials.title: FOCUS ABILITIES
tutorials.bodyHTML:
Heroes are also capable of casting special powers known as Focus Abilities. Flip each Hero board to its Advanced side—this version features new Skills and the Focus Abilities.

  • When casting a Focus Ability, the Hero must discard the appropriate number of FOCUS tokens. Casting a Focus Ability that is not a Reaction () costs a Minor Action.
  • Focus Abilities that are Reactions may only be used as Reactions and do not cost a Minor Action.
  • The Range of performed when using Focus Abilities is determined by the category of the Weapon the Hero is wielding: Melee Weapons use Melee Range; Ranged Weapons have Range 1.
  • All other effects of Focus Abilities have Unlimited Range.
  • FOCUS tokens are Stackable Resources. Each Hero may have up to 4 of them at a time.

Once you have finished reading these topics, continue the Adventure and begin the battle against the Undead King.
